baseline_groups.claim_summary: Real export prices and real import prices are highly positively correlated across OECD countries (corr(px, pm) ~ 0.75-0.85), computed as the cross-country average of HP-filtered pairwise correlations.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 1. Baseline: HP(1600), full sample 1980-2004, CPI deflator, all 12 countries. Estimate = 0.7953. This is the paper's core motivating fact (Fact 1). The paper reports the cross-country average correlation and emphasizes that it is strongly positive.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The terms of trade are much less volatile than the real exchange rate: SD(TOT)/SD(RER) is substantially below 1 (typically 0.5-0.7).
baseline_groups.notes: Table 2. Baseline: HP(1600), full sample 1980-2004, CPI deflator, all 12 countries. Estimate = 0.5688. The claim is that this ratio is well below 1, meaning terms of trade are less volatile than the real exchange rate (Fact 2).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The volatility of the quantity ratio (product mix) is comparable to or slightly below the volatility of the price ratio: SD(Q)/SD(P) ~ 0.8-0.9.
baseline_groups.notes: Table 3. Baseline: HP(1600), shorter sample 1980-2000, national accounts deflator, all 12 countries. Estimate = 0.7939. The claim is that quantity adjustment is not dramatically larger than price adjustment (Fact 3). Note the baseline uses the shorter sample (1980-2000) and national accounts deflators, matching the paper's Table 3.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Real export prices are consistently less volatile than the real exchange rate: SD(px)/SD(RER) is below 1 (typically 0.5-0.7).
baseline_groups.notes: Supporting statistic complementing Table 2 findings. Baseline: HP(1600), full sample 1980-2004, CPI deflator, all 12 countries. Estimate = 0.6140. This measures how much of real exchange rate volatility is transmitted to export prices.

global_notes: Paper is 'Understanding International Prices: Customers as Capital' by Drozd & Nosal (AER 2012). This is a descriptive statistics / calibration targets paper -- no regression analysis. The empirical content consists of computing cross-country averages of correlations and volatility ratios on HP-filtered (or otherwise detrended) macroeconomic time series from OECD national accounts data (1980Q1-2004Q2, 12 countries). The specification search systematically varies 5 dimensions: (1) detrending method (HP, linear, first-diff), (2) HP filter parameter (7 values), (3) sample period (8 windows), (4) price deflator (CPI vs PPI for Facts 1-2; national accounts for Fact 3), and (5) country subset (8 subsets). The 16 corr_EPI_IPI_nominal specs (nominal export-import price correlations) lack a flagged baseline; the natural baseline (spec 2881: hp1600, full sample, all 12 countries) is assigned to G1 as a supplementary statistic since it measures the same correlation concept without real deflation. Total: 3064 specs across 5 outcome statistics. Small numerical differences from published values arise because the specification search uses the OECD REER directly rather than constructing a trade-weighted RER from bilateral exchange rates with time-varying weights as in the original MATLAB code.
